channel.title: nlin.PS updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: nlin.PS updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Nonlinear quadrupole topological insulators
item.description: arXiv:2602.06851v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Higher-order topological insulators (HOTIs) represent a family of topological phases that go beyond the conventional bulkboundary correspondence. d-dimensional n-th order HOTIs maintain (d - n)-dimensional gapless boundary states (in particular, zero-dimensional corner states in the case of d = n = 2). HOTIs of the Wannier type cam be extended into the nonlinear regime. Another prominent class of HOTIs, in the form of multipole insulators, was investigated only in the linear regime, due to the challenge of simultaneously achieving both negative hopping and strong nonlinearity. Here we propose the concept of nonlinear quadrupole topological insulators (NLQTIs) and report their experimental realization in an electric circuit lattice. Quench-initiated dynamics gives rise to nonlinear topological corner states and topologically trivial corner solitons, in weakly and strongly nonlinear regimes, respectively. Furthermore, we reveal the formation of two distinct types of bulk solitons, one existing in the middle finite gap under the action of weak nonlinearity, and another one found in the semi-infinite gap under strong nonlinearity. This work realizes another member of the nonlinear HOTI family, suggesting directions for exploring novel solitons across a broad range of topological insulators.
item.dc:creator: Rujiang Li, Wencai Wang, Yongtao Jia, Ying Liu, Pengfei Li, Boris A. Malomed

item.title: Strongly chirped dissipative solitons in normal and anomalous dispersion regimes
item.description: arXiv:2509.22806v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We investigate the strongly chirped dissipative solitons of the cubic-quintic complex Ginzburg-Landau equation and identify the parameter domains that support robust stationary pulse solutions. Using algebraic solvability conditions, we map the existence regions for the two branches of the chirped solution in the three-dimensional space of control parameters and clarify how these regions transform between the normal- and anomalous-dispersion regimes. A central outcome is that the dissipative soliton resonance arises naturally on the energy-scalable branch. In the normal group-velocity dispersion region, it follows directly from the admissibility constraints, while for the anomalous group-velocity dispersion, it appears only once the resonance locus intersects an adiabatic existence window, which requires sufficiently strong quintic self-phase modulation. These results provide a pathway toward high-energy femtosecond pulse oscillators. We also outline a consistent thermodynamic perspective on the phase-space structure obtained, emphasizing analogies with phase transitions and critical behavior in dissipative nonlinear systems.
item.dc:creator: V. L. Kalashnikov, A. Rudenkov, E. Sorokin, I. T. Sorokina
